message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A Time-Dependent SIR Model for COVID-19 With Undetectable Infected Persons
Paper Abstract: In this paper, we conduct mathematical and numerical analyses for COVID-19. To predict the trend of COVID-19, we propose a time-dependent SIR model that tracks the transmission and recovering rate at time [Formula: see text]. Using the data provided by China authority, we show our one-day prediction errors are almost less than [Formula: see text]. The turning point and the total number of confirmed cases in China are predicted under our model. To analyze the impact of the undetectable infections on the spread of disease, we extend our model by considering two types of infected persons: detectable and undetectable infected persons. Whether there is an outbreak is characterized by the spectral radius of a [Formula: see text] matrix. If [Formula: see text], then the spectral radius of that matrix is greater than 1, and there is an outbreak. We plot the phase transition diagram of an outbreak and show that there are several countries on the verge of COVID-19 outbreaks on Mar. 2, 2020. To illustrate the effectiveness of social distancing, we analyze the independent cascade model for disease propagation in a configuration random network. We show two approaches of social distancing that can lead to a reduction of the effective reproduction number [Formula: see text].
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "SIR model epidemiology"

Links: [{"title":"Compartmental models (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Compartmental_models_in_epidemiology"},{"title":"Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the SIR model in epidemiology:

## What is the SIR Model?

The SIR model is a classic compartmental model in epidemiology used as a simple model for modelling epidemics.(no content)The SIR model is one of the simplest compartmental models, and many models are derivatives of this basic form.

## Components

The variables (S, I, and R) represent the number of people in each compartment at a particular time. Specifically:
- **S (Susceptible)**: People who can contract the disease
- **I (Infectious)**: Individuals who have been infected with the disease and are capable of spreading the disease to those in the susceptible category
- **R (Removed)**: The compartment for individuals who have been infected and then removed from the disease, either due to immunization or due to death. Those in this category are not able to be infected again or to transmit the infection to others.

## Applications and Uses

Epidemiologists and public health officials use these models for analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting the total number of infections and recoveries over time, estimating key epidemiological parameters such as the basic reproduction number (R0) or effective reproduction number (Rt), evaluating potential impacts of different public health interventions before implementation, and informing evidence-based policy decisions during disease outbreaks.

## Applicability

This model is reasonably predictive for infectious diseases that are transmitted from human to human, and where recovery confers lasting resistance, such as measles, mumps, and rubella.

## Related Models

There are many modifications of the SIR model, including those that include births and deaths, where upon recovery there is no immunity (SIS model), where immunity lasts only for a short period of time (SIRS), where there is a latent period of the disease where the person is not infectious (SEIS and SEIR), and where infants can be born with immunity (MSIR).

## What is the SIR Model?

The SIR model is a classic compartmental model in epidemiology used as a simple model for modelling epidemics.(no content)The SIR model is one of the simplest compartmental models, and many models are derivatives of this basic form.

## Components

The variables (S, I, and R) represent the number of people in each compartment at a particular time. Specifically:

- **R (Removed)**: The compartment for individuals who have been infected and then removed from the disease, either due to immunization or due to death. Those in this category are not able to be infected again or to transmit the infection to others.

## Applications and Uses

Epidemiologists and public health officials use these models for analyzing disease transmission dynamics, projecting the total number of infections and recoveries over time, estimating key epidemiological parameters such as the basic reproduction number (R0) or effective reproduction number (Rt), evaluating potential impacts of different public health interventions before implementation, and informing evidence-based policy decisions during disease outbreaks.

## Applicability

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Basic reproduction number"

Links: [{"title":"Basic reproduction number - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Basic_reproduction_number"},{"title":"R0 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R0"},{"title":"Next-generation matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Next-generation_matrix"},{"title":"Ashok Agarwal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashok_Agarwal"},{"title":"Force of infection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Force_of_infection"}]

Here are the search results for "Basic reproduction number":

## Overview

The basic reproduction number (R₀, pronounced "R nought" or "R zero") of an infection is the expected number of cases directly generated by one case in a population where all individuals are susceptible to infection.

## Key Factors

The basic reproduction number is affected by several factors, including the duration of infectivity of affected people, the contagiousness of the microorganism, and the number of susceptible people in the population that the infected people contact.

## Historical Background

The roots of the basic reproduction concept can be traced through the work of Ronald Ross, Alfred Lotka and others, but its first modern application in epidemiology was by George Macdonald in 1952, who constructed population models of the spread of malaria.

## Mathematical Calculation

The basic reproduction number can be computed as a ratio of known rates over time: if a contagious individual contacts β other people per unit time, if all of those people are assumed to contract the disease, and if the disease has a mean infectious period, then R₀ equals β divided by γ.

## Applications

In compartmental models used for mathematical modeling of infectious diseases, population members are assigned to 'compartments' with labels such as S, I, or R (Susceptible, Infectious, or Recovered).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Social distancing"

Links: [{"title":"Social distancing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distancing"},{"title":"Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distancing_measures_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic"},{"title":"Talk:Social distancing measures related to the COVID-19 pandemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Draft_talk:Social_distancing_in_the_construction_industry"},{"title":"Loneliness in old age - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Loneliness_in_old_age"},{"title":"Michele Meyer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michele_Meyer"},{"title":"Begin Again (South Korean TV program) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Begin_Again_(South_Korean_TV_program)"},{"title":"Social transformation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_transformation"},{"title":"X-Mode social - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Mode_social"}]

## Social Distancing Overview

Social distancing usually involves keeping a certain distance from others and avoiding gathering together in larger groups.(no content)According to the CDC, social distancing is "a set of methods for reducing frequency and closeness of contact between people in order to decrease the risk of transmission of disease".

### Purpose and Implementation

Social distancing measures are used to slow down the spread of infectious diseases and avoid overburdening healthcare systems, particularly during a pandemic, and include closing schools and workplaces, isolation, quarantine, restricting people's movement and cancelling mass gatherings.(no content)Social distancing measures are most effective when the infectious disease spreads via droplet contact (coughing or sneezing), direct physical contact, indirect physical contact (such as by touching a contaminated surface), or airborne transmission.

### Recommended Distances

The specific distances recommended vary. During the COVID-19 pandemic, the World Health Organization recommends that a distance of 1 m (3.3 ft) or more is safe. However, the CDC defined social distancing during COVID-19 as "remaining out of congregate settings, avoiding mass gatherings, and maintaining distance (approximately six feet or two meters) from others when possible".

### Drawbacks

Drawbacks of social distancing can include loneliness, reduced productivity and the loss of other benefits associated with human interaction.

### Historical Note

The term "social distancing" was not introduced until 2003.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "COVID-19". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a contagious disease caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.(no content)In January 2020, the disease spread worldwide, resulting in the COVID-19 pandemic.

## Origins and Timeline

The first known case was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.(no content)The official names COVID‑19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued by the WHO on 11 February 2020 with COVID-19 being shorthand for "coronavirus disease 2019".

## Symptoms

Common symptoms include coughing, fever, loss of smell and taste, with less common ones including headaches, nasal congestion and runny nose, muscle pain, sore throat, diarrhea, eye irritation, and toes swelling or turning purple, and in moderate to severe cases, breathing difficulties.

## Transmission and Prevention

COVID‑19 transmission occurs when infectious particles are breathed in or come into contact with the eyes, nose, or mouth. The risk is highest when people are in close proximity, but small airborne particles containing the virus can remain suspended in the air and travel over longer distances, particularly indoors.(no content)Other preventive measures include physical or social distancing, quarantining, ventilation of indoor spaces, use of face masks or coverings in public, covering coughs and sneezes, hand washing, and keeping unwashed hands away from the face.

## Current Status and Impact

The WHO declared the public health emergency caused by COVID-19 had ended in May 2023. However, the disease has continued to circulate since 2023.(no content)As of 12 December 2025, COVID-19 has caused 7,102,614 confirmed deaths, and 18.2 to 33.5 million estimated deaths.

I've completed the web search for "COVID-19". Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Overview

Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is a contagious disease caused by the coronavirus SARS-CoV-2.(no content)In January 2020, the disease spread worldwide, resulting in the COVID-19 pandemic.

## Origins and Timeline

The first known case was identified in Wuhan, China, in December 2019.(no content)The official names COVID‑19 and SARS-CoV-2 were issued by the WHO on 11 February 2020 with COVID-19 being shorthand for "coronavirus disease 2019".

## Symptoms

Common symptoms include coughing, fever, loss of smell and taste, with less common ones including headaches, nasal congestion and runny nose, muscle pain, sore throat, diarrhea, eye irritation, and toes swelling or turning purple, and in moderate to severe cases, breathing difficulties.

## Transmission and Prevention

COVID‑19 transmission occurs when infectious particles are breathed in or come into contact with the eyes, nose, or mouth. The risk is highest when people are in close proximity, but small airborne particles containing the virus can remain suspended in the air and travel over longer distances, particularly indoors.(no content)Other preventive measures include physical or social distancing, quarantining, ventilation of indoor spaces, use of face masks or coverings in public, covering coughs and sneezes, hand washing, and keeping unwashed hands away from the face.

## Current Status and Impact

The WHO declared the public health emergency caused by COVID-19 had ended in May 2023. However, the disease has continued to circulate since 2023.(no content)As of 12 December 2025, COVID-19 has caused 7,102,614 confirmed deaths, and 18.2 to 33.5 million estimated deaths.

Web search results for query: "Spectral radius matrix"

Links: [{"title":"Spectral radius - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_radius"},{"title":"Spectrum of a matrix - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_of_a_matrix"},{"title":"Joint spectral radius - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Joint_spectral_radius"},{"title":"Matrix norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matrix_norm"},{"title":"Perron–Frobenius theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Perron–Frobenius_theorem"},{"title":"Operator norm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operator_norm"},{"title":"Power iteration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_iteration"},{"title":"Spectrum (functional analysis) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectrum_(functional_analysis)"},{"title":"Spectral gap - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_gap"},{"title":"Spectral theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spectral_theory"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the spectral radius of a matrix:

## Definition

The spectral radius of a square matrix is the maximum of the absolute values of its eigenvalues.(no content)It is the largest absolute value of its eigenvalues.

## Key Properties

**Relationship to Matrix Behavior:** The spectral radius is closely related to the behavior of the convergence of the power sequence of a matrix. Specifically, ρ(A) < 1 if and only if the limit of ||A^k|| equals zero as k approaches infinity.

**Bounds with Matrix Norms:** In general, the spectral radius of A is bounded above by the operator norm of A: ρ(A) ≤ ||A||_op.

**Applications:** In many applications, such as PageRank, one is interested in the dominant eigenvalue, i.e. that which is largest in absolute value.

## Special Cases

**Perron-Frobenius Theorem:** If A is a positive (or more generally primitive) matrix, then there exists a real positive eigenvalue r (Perron–Frobenius eigenvalue or Perron root), which is strictly greater in absolute value than all other eigenvalues, hence r is the spectral radius of A.

**Symmetric Matrices:** For symmetric or hermitian A, we have equality in the spectral radius formula for the 2-norm, since in this case the 2-norm is precisely the spectral radius of A.

## Computational Methods

The method can also be used to calculate the spectral radius (the eigenvalue with the largest magnitude, for a square matrix) by computing the Rayleigh quotient.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Random network graph theory"

Links: [{"title":"Random graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_graph"},{"title":"Erdős–Rényi model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erdős–Rényi_model"},{"title":"Random geometric graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Random_geometric_graph"},{"title":"Configuration model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Configuration_model"},{"title":"Rado graph - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rado_graph"},{"title":"Small-world network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small-world_network"},{"title":"Graph theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory"},{"title":"Network science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_science"},{"title":"Network theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_theory"},{"title":"Scale-free network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale-free_network"}]

Based on the search results, here's a comprehensive overview of random network graph theory:

## Definition and Fundamentals

The theory of random graphs lies at the intersection between graph theory and probability theory.(no content)In mathematics, random graph is the general term to refer to probability distributions over graphs.(no content)A random graph is obtained by starting with a set of n isolated vertices and adding successive edges between them at random.

## Key Models

### Erdős–Rényi Model
The Erdős–Rényi model of random graphs was first defined by Paul Erdős and Alfréd Rényi in their 1959 paper "On Random Graphs" and independently by Gilbert in his paper "Random graphs".(no content)In the model of Erdős and Rényi, all graphs on a fixed vertex set with a fixed number of edges are equally likely. In the model introduced by Gilbert, also called the Erdős–Rényi–Gilbert model, each edge has a fixed probability of being present or absent, independently of the other edges.

### Other Models
A random geometric graph (RGG) is an undirected graph constructed by randomly placing N nodes in some metric space (according to a specified probability distribution) and connecting two nodes by a link if and only if their distance is in a given range.(no content)In network science, the Configuration Model is a family of random graph models designed to generate networks from a given degree sequence. Unlike simpler models such as the Erdős–Rényi model, Configuration Models preserve the degree of each vertex as a pre-defined property.

## Applications and Properties

Its practical applications are found in all areas in which complex networks need to be modeled – many random graph models are thus known, mirroring the diverse types of complex networks encountered in different areas.(no content)Percolation theory characterizes the connectedness of random graphs, especially infinitely large ones. Percolation is related to the robustness of the graph (called also network).(no content)These models can be used in the probabilistic method to prove the existence of graphs satisfying various properties, or to provide a rigorous definition of what it means for a property to hold for almost all graphs.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Information cascade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_cascade"},{"title":"Global cascades model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Global_cascades_model"},{"title":"Cascading classifiers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_classifiers"},{"title":"Linear-nonlinear-Poisson cascade model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear-nonlinear-Poisson_cascade_model"},{"title":"Cascade Model of Relational Dissolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascade_Model_of_Relational_Dissolution"},{"title":"Availability cascade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Availability_cascade"},{"title":"Cascades in financial networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascades_in_financial_networks"},{"title":"Two-port network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Two-port_network"},{"title":"Cascading failure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascading_failure"},{"title":"Cascade effect (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cascade_effect_(ecology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of cascade models in network theory:

## Information Cascades

An information cascade is a phenomenon described in behavioral economics and network theory in which a number of people make the same decision in a sequential fashion.(no content)An information cascade is generally accepted as a two-step process. For a cascade to begin an individual must encounter a scenario with a decision, typically a binary one. Second, outside factors can influence this decision, such as the individual observing others' choices and the apparent outcomes.(no content)Information cascades occur when external information obtained from previous participants in an event overrides one's own private signal, irrespective of the correctness of the former over the latter.

## Global Cascades Model

Global cascades models are a class of models aiming to model large and rare cascades that are triggered by exogenous perturbations which are relatively small compared with the size of the system. The phenomenon occurs ubiquitously in various systems, like information cascades in social systems, stock market crashes in economic systems, and cascading failure in physics infrastructure networks.(no content)A network-based threshold model has been proposed by Duncan J. Watts in 2002. The model is motivated by considering a population of individuals who must make a decision between two alternatives, and their choices depend explicitly on other people's states or choices. The model assumes that an individual will adopt a new particular opinion (product or state) if a threshold fraction of his/her neighbors have adopted the new one, else he would keep his original state.

## Other Applications

Cascade models extend to various domains, including cascades in financial networks—situations in which the failure of one financial institution causes a cascading failure in another member of the financial network, and cascading failures in systems of interconnected parts in which the failure of one or few parts leads to the failure of other parts, growing progressively as a result of positive feedback.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Disease outbreak epidemiology"

Links: [{"title":"Disease outbreak - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_outbreak"},{"title":"List of epidemics and pandemics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_epidemics_and_pandemics"},{"title":"Epidemic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic"},{"title":"Epidemic curve - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemic_curve"},{"title":"Mathematical modelling of infectious diseases - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mathematical_modelling_of_infectious_diseases"},{"title":"Outbreak response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outbreak_response"},{"title":"Epidemiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epidemiology"},{"title":"Disease surveillance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disease_surveillance"},{"title":"Category:Disease outbreaks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Disease_outbreaks"},{"title":"Endemic (epidemiology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endemic_(epidemiology)"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about disease outbreak epidemiology:

## Definition of Disease Outbreak

In epidemiology, an outbreak is a sudden increase in occurrences of a disease when cases are in excess of normal expectancy for the location or season.(no content)It may affect a small and localized group or impact upon thousands of people across an entire continent.

## Key Concepts

An epidemic is the rapid spread of disease to a large number of hosts in a given population within a short period of time.(no content)A pandemic occurs when an epidemic spreads worldwide.

## Outbreak Investigation Steps

When investigating disease outbreaks, the epidemiology profession has developed a number of widely accepted steps, which include identifying the existence of the outbreak (Is the group of ill persons normal for the time of year, geographic area, etc.?).(no content)Prevention and control measures are usually implemented very early in the investigation, often before the causative agent is known.

## Outbreak Patterns

There are several outbreak patterns, which can be useful in identifying the transmission method or source, and predicting the future rate of infection. These include:

- Point source – Common source outbreak where the exposure occurs in less than one incubation period; Propagated – Transmission occurs from person to person.
- Zoonotic – The infectious agent is endemic to an animal population, infection is transferred to humans.

## Outbreak Response

The basic strategies in the control of an outbreak are containment and mitigation, with containment involving contact tracing and isolating infected individuals to stop the disease from being spread.(no content)A key part of managing an infectious disease outbreak is trying to decrease the epidemic peak, which helps decrease the risk of health services being overwhelmed and provides more time for a vaccine and treatment to be developed.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

3. **Spectral radius** (concept, uses) - Used to determine outbreak conditions
4. **Basic reproduction number** (concept, uses) - Analyzes transmission rates
5. **Social distancing** (concept, uses) - Public health intervention analyzed
6. **Global cascades model** (method, uses) - Disease propagation modeling
7. **Configuration model** (method, uses) - Network topology for disease spread
8. **Disease outbreak** (task, uses) - Core problem being addressed
9. **Time-dependent stochastic model** (method, proposes) - The novel contribution
